TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in LOC ) .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was charged in GPE with blackmail within the meaning of Article CARDINAL of LAW ( Law no . QUANTITY . , as applicable at the relevant time ) .

CARDINAL . The charge was based on the suspicion that the applicant had sent a number of text messages from a NORP mobile telephone number to NORP in GPE which contained serious threats that he would harm and kill her and their child .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was handed over to the NORP authorities to be prosecuted in GPE . He was subsequently detained in GPE pending trial there ( see below ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG súd ) found the applicant guilty as charged and sentenced him to DATE imprisonment , suspended for DATE . The applicant waived his right of appeal and , on DATE , the judgment became final and binding and the applicant was released .

CARDINAL . In so far as can be established from the applicant 's submissions and the content of the documents in the case file , on DATE a single judge of ORG gave an order ( uznesenie ) for the applicant to be detained pending trial . The order was upheld following an interlocutory appeal ( sťažnosť ) by the applicant examined by ORG ( PERSON súd ) on DATE . The decision on the appeal was served on the applicant 's lawyer on DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant lodged a complaint with ORG ( Ústavný súd ) under LAW .

The applicant relied on LAW and contended that his detention was unlawful and arbitrary since there was neither any “ reasonable suspicion ” with a basis in admissible evidence against him nor sufficient reasons to detain him . The applicant also argued that the impugned decisions lacked adequate reasoning and that the proceedings on his interlocutory appeal had not been speedy . He sought , inter alia , that the decision of CARDINAL DATE be quashed , that he be released and that ORG be ordered to determine his interlocutory appeal anew .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG declared the complaint admissible .

CARDINAL . In a written submission of CARDINAL DATE the applicant , inter alia , requested for comment a copy of any observations that ORG and ORG , as the defendants in the proceedings before ORG , might have submitted in reply to his complaint .

CARDINAL . On DATE the Constitutional Court gave a judgment ( nález ) in which it found that ORG had violated the applicant 's rights under LAW in that it had failed to provide adequate reasoning for its decision of DATE and in that the proceedings on the applicant 's interlocutory appeal had not been speedy .

CARDINAL . The Constitutional Court quashed the decision of CARDINAL DATE . It observed that the applicant had meanwhile been released . The part of his constitutional complaint , which was aimed at his release and at a fresh examination of his interlocutory appeal , had therefore become moot . Nevertheless , while accepting that the applicant had sustained non - pecuniary damage , ORG did not award him any just satisfaction on the ground that the finding of a violation of the applicant 's rights was sufficient redress for him . However , ORG allowed a part of the applicant 's claim for legal costs

CARDINAL . ORG took into account observations made in reply to the applicant 's complaint by ORG and ORG but made no mention of the part of the applicant 's complaint which concerned the substantive aspects of his detention .
CARDINAL . The judgment of ORG was served on the applicant through the intermediary of his lawyer on DATE . No appeal lay against it .

CARDINAL . In so far as can be established from the applicant 's submissions and the content of the documents in the case file , on CARDINAL May CARDINAL the applicant requested release , offered a pledge , under LAW ( b ) of LAW ( Law no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL Coll . , as applicable at the relevant time ) ( “ the ORG ” ) , that he would live in accordance with the law and , as an alternative , applied for bail under LAW ORG .
CARDINAL . By law the request fell to be determined first by the regional prosecutor , who dismissed it and on DATE forwarded it ex officio to ORG for judicial determination .

CARDINAL . The request for release was then dismissed in turn by a CARDINAL - judge bench of ORG on DATE and , on an interlocutory appeal by the applicant , by ORG on DATE . The decision on the appeal was served on the applicant on DATE .
CARDINAL . NORP The applicant challenged the decisions and various aspects of the procedure by way of CARDINAL complaints under LAW .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG declared inadmissible the complaint by which the applicant had mainly challenged the length of the proceedings in respect of his request for release , in so far as these proceedings had taken place before the public prosecution service and ORG .

ORG found that any possible delays on the part of the public prosecution service had been insignificant and that , in so far as ORG was concerned , the complaint was manifestly ill - founded on the ground that , at the time of its introduction with ORG , the request for release was no longer pending before ORG , which was why the applicant was no longer in need of protection by ORG .
The decision of ORG was served on the applicant on DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG declared inadmissible as manifestly ill - founded a part of the applicant 's outstanding constitutional complaint , which concerned the fact that the decision of DATE had wrongfully been made by a bench whereas the body authorised to make it was a single judge . ORG declared admissible the remainder of the complaint , as specified below . The decision was served on the applicant on DATE .

CARDINAL . NORP In a judgment of DATE ORG found that there had been a violation of the applicant 's rights under LAW , DATE of the ORG , in that ORG had failed to provide the applicant with a copy of the observations made by the prosecution service in reply to the applicant 's request for release , combined with the fact that it had also failed to hear the applicant in person , rule on all claims in the appeal and provide adequate reasoning for its decision . Moreover , the proceedings before both ORG and ORG had not been “ speedy ” . In reaching this last conclusion ORG observed that , prior to the ordinary court 's involvement in deciding on the applicant 's request for release , his request had been examined by the public prosecution service . ORG found no issue in the length of the proceedings before the public prosecution service .
CARDINAL . ORG held that there was no point in quashing the decision of ORG in view of the fact that the applicant had meanwhile been released .
CARDINAL . The applicant was awarded CARDINAL NORP korunas ( SKK ) in just satisfaction for non - pecuniary damage and the reimbursement of legal costs .
The judgment was served on the applicant 's lawyer on CARDINAL DATE .

CARDINAL . Until DATE State liability for damage caused by decisions concerning pre - trial detention was governed by LAW hlava ) CARDINAL of Part ( časť ) CARDINAL of the Act on State Liability for Damage Caused by ORG Decisions or ORG ( PERSON o zodpovednosti za škodu spôsobenú rozhodnutím orgánu štátu alebo jeho nesprávnym úradným postupom – “ LAW DATE ” ) .
CARDINAL . Persons deprived of their liberty had a claim against the ORG for damages when the criminal proceedings against them were dropped or they were acquitted ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ) .

However , such compensation was excluded when the persons concerned were responsible for their own detention , in particular when they had tried to abscond or had otherwise given rise to the facts on which the decision concerning their detention was based .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL ) rendered the ORG liable for damage caused in the context of carrying out functions vested in public authorities resulting from wrongful official action of persons entrusted with the exercise of those functions . An award of compensation could be made when the plaintiff showed that he or she had suffered damage as a result of the wrongful official action of a public authority , quantified its amount , and showed that there was a causal link between the damage and the wrongful action in question .

CARDINAL . LAW DATE was traditionally interpreted and applied as not allowing for compensation to be awarded for non - pecuniary damage unless it was related to the deterioration of a person 's health ( see , for example , GPE v. GPE , no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL , § CARDINAL , DATE , and GPE v. GPE ( dec . ) , no . CARDINAL , CARDINAL DATE ) .

CARDINAL . By its judgment of CARDINAL DATE in an appeal on points of law ( no . DATE ) concerning an action for damages under LAW DATE , ORG upheld the view that neither that LAW nor an action for protection of personal integrity provided a legal basis for awarding compensation in respect of non - pecuniary damage caused by unlawful detention .
LAW DATE was , however , to be interpreted in line with LAW which presupposed compensation for non - pecuniary damage and , pursuant to LAW , prevailed over the statutory text .
This line of reasoning was followed in judgments of ORG of DATE and ORG of DATE when deciding on appeals nos . CARDINALCo DATE and ORG .
CARDINAL . In DATE the Minister of ORG submitted to the Government a draft bill providing for a new legislative framework for official liability .

The bill was accompanied by an introductory report ( predkladacia správa ) in which the Minister observed , inter alia , that the old State Liability Act had been on the statute book since DATE and that , owing to subsequent changes to the social system and the adoption of the Convention , there was a new understanding of the concept of ORG liability for damage , which called for the introduction of new legislation .

CARDINAL . The bill was later submitted to ORG with an explanatory report , the relevant part of which stated that it was necessary to extend the current concept of the right to damages to incorporate just satisfaction in respect of non - pecuniary damage as well as pecuniary damage . The purpose of the proposed LAW was , inter alia , to render the mechanism of compensation for damage caused by public authorities more effective and thereby reduce the number of cases in which claimants were obliged to seek redress before ORG .
CARDINAL . The bill was adopted with effect from DATE ( PERSON o zodpovednosti za škodu spôsobenú pri výkone verejnej moci ) and replaced LAW DATE .

CARDINAL . The right to compensation for damage caused by a decision concerning detention on remand ( väzba ) is vested in the person who was detained on remand provided that the criminal proceedings against him or her have been dropped ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(a ) ) or he or she has been acquitted ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(b ) ) or the matter has been referred to another authority ( section CARDINAL ) ) .
CARDINAL . However , no such right arises when the person concerned himself or herself gave cause to the detention on remand ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(a ) ) .

CARDINAL . The ORG is also liable for damage caused by wrongful official action which comprises , inter alia , a public authority 's failure to take action within the time - limit set , inactivity or any other unlawful interference with rights and legally recognised interests of individuals and legal entities ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ) .
CARDINAL . The right to compensation for damage caused by wrongful official action is vested in the person who suffered the damage ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ) .
CARDINAL . Under LAW the compensation is to cover pecuniary damage , including loss of profit , and , where appropriate and necessary , nonpecuniary damage .
CARDINAL . The Act applies only to damage caused by decisions and wrongful official action occurring after it entered into force ( section ORG ) ) .
